speaker: Gil
text: Well, look who's up! _SMASH CUT TO: Frasier sits up in bed - his own bed.  The previous scene had been a dream - or a nightmare, considering Frasier's panic-stricken reaction.  FADE OUT_ **WHY GIL?  WHY NOW?** _Scene Two - KACL. Frasier is listening to a young male caller, Jimmy._

speaker: Jimmy
text: [_v.o._] So it's my parents.  I don't know, they're just like, really stupid.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_bored_] May I ask how old you are?

speaker: Jimmy
text: Fourteen.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, hang on, Jimmy.  Your parents are going to be stupid for another seven years.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Whoa!  Seven years?  That's like, longer than I'll be in high school!

speaker: Frasier
text: I salute your optimism. [_disconnects_] We'll be right back after this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh god, Roz.  A teenager who's embarrassed by his parents? I mean, please.  Can't you come up with something a little more challenging for me?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, it was either him or our old pal, Rudy the Crier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Rudy the Crier.  Oh God.  He's been on three times in the last month.  You put him on again, he won't be the only one who's crying.  God, I'm in a dry spell.  Where are the souls in genuine torment?  The people teetering on the brink of genuine despair?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, they'll be back.  The holidays are just around the corner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps you're right.  Oh, Roz, I've got a question I'd like to ask you.

speaker: Roz
text: Shoot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you ever had a recurring dream of an intimate nature about someone... oh, a... well, a co-worker?

speaker: Roz
text: [_disgusted_] Oh, no.  Why'd you tell me?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, now it's gonna be creepy everytime you look at me through the glass!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, not you!

speaker: Roz
text: [_intrigued_] So who is it then?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm not going to go into the specifics.

speaker: Roz
text: Gina in accounting?

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, I'm not gonna do this!

speaker: Roz
text: Sheila, the slow intern?

speaker: Frasier
text: Forget I even mentioned it.

speaker: Gil
text: Knock knock...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_suddenly nervous_] Gil? [_Roz eyes Frasier suspiciously_]

speaker: Gil
text: Frasier, I've come to tempt you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_scared_] Really?

speaker: Gil
text: I'm reviewing the new pastry chef at Chez Shea. [_reveals an eclair_] And I quote: "His amaretto eclair is so sinful, it will send you scurrying to your local padre for absolution."

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... no, thank you, Gil.  I'm on a diet.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, come now!  You know you want it...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_jumping up_] Oh, no no no... I really don't! [_shoos Gil out the door_] Off you go.  Bye-bye.

speaker: Roz
text: [_excited_] Oh, my god!

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Roz
text: It was Gil!

speaker: Frasier
text: I never said that!

speaker: Roz
text: Then why are you blushing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't be ridiculous!

speaker: Roz
text: Your ears are turning bright red!

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not blushing!

speaker: Roz
text: You are! _Gil then knocks on one of the windows.  As they look at him he takes a big bite out of the eclair.  Frasier hurriedly closes the blinds as Roz laughs._

speaker: Frasier
text: Still not blushing!

speaker: Rudy
text: [_v.o._] ...just lying there in the hospital bed.  She lifted her head off the pillow, looked up and said, "I love you," and then she was gone. [_cries_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Rudy, stop crying.  We've gone over this before.  What was our agreement about sad movies?

speaker: Rudy
text: I shouldn't watch them. [_cries_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly.  Now go get a cool washcloth and try to bring down the puffiness around your eyes.  Please... stay away from sad or depressing things... which, at this moment, includes listening to the Dr. Frasier Crane Show. [_disconnects_] Well, let's shoot it to the news.  That's it for today.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane. [_he goes off air and Roz enters_] Oh, my God!  Well, close the record books.  That was just the dullest three hours in the history of the Frasier Crane Show!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on.  It wasn't so bad.  What about that woman who was so concerned about her appearance she wouldn't leave the house?

speaker: Frasier
text: That was a commercial!  I believe Miss Clairol solved the problem!  Well, I'll see you tomorrow. [_he moves to exit, then turns back_] Oh!  Oh, Roz... about that dream I mentioned to you earlier... uh... this goes without saying, but I'd rather you didn't share that with anyone else.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, sure.

speaker: Betty
text: [_passing by_] Hi, dreamboy!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Roz_] I hate you!  Couldn't keep your big mouth shut, could you?  Just exactly when did you find the time to spread the news?

speaker: Roz
text: You don't think I was listening to your show, do you?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Comin' through!  Oh, Doc... I got to rub this one in a little...

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, look, Bulldog... before you start to ridicule me, yes, yes I had a dream about Gil.  And yes, it had some erotic elements, but... [_notices Bulldog's surprised expression_] You have absolutely no idea what I'm talking about, do you?

speaker: Bulldog
text: I do now!  Whoa! [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, let's just forget it.  What delightful little jibe did you have prepared for me?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, I was gonna tell you your show today just broke the snooze meter, but now I want to hear about you greasin' Gil's cookie sheet! [_honks horn_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm on a bus to Hell. **PSYCHIATRIST...CRANE... FRASIER...NILES...IDIOTS**  _Scene Three - Cafe Nervosa. Frasier and Niles are standing at the counter.  Niles is relaying a story to a bored Frasier._

speaker: Niles
text: So I returned to the dry-cleaners yet a third time.  I hardly need to tell you how the story ends.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just tell me _when_ the story ends.

speaker: Niles
text: [_miffed_] Fine.  They realigned my pleats, The End.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sorry, Niles. [_they get their coffees and sit at a nearby table_] I'm just a bit distracted today.  You see, this morning, a... a man from my building approached me with a very intriguing problem.  It seems he's been having a recurring dream.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, please.  That little gambit didn't work when we were in knee socks.  What was your dream, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right!  It's been tormenting me.  I haven't been able to sleep in weeks now.  It's a bit hazy but... it starts out in a seedy motel room.  I'm naked.

speaker: Niles
text: Interesting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well... I roll over and discover on my forearm a tattoo: the word "Chesty."

speaker: Niles
text: Interesting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Then the shower turns off and out from the bathroom steps... a man. [_pause_] All right, go ahead, let me have it!

speaker: Niles
text: Are you saying that now, or is that a quote from the dream?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed_] Please?  We're both too intelligent to waste time on the obvious interpretation.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  But you must admit, it's rather intriguing. [_chuckles_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you stop?  It's obviously screaming for a Jungian interpretation.  The sexuality in the dream is surely symbolic of some deeper, non-sexual conflict.

speaker: Niles
text: All right.

speaker: Gil
text: Good afternoon, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gil.

speaker: Gil
text: A little birdie tells me I was featured in your midnight movie.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's very clever.  Off you go.

speaker: Gil
text: Very well.  I'll see you tomorrow.  Or should I say, "See you in your dreams"? [_exits_]

speaker: Niles
text: In this dream of yours, were there any cigars, bananas or short, blunt swords?

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you stop it?!  I'm 43 - a little late for latency.

speaker: Rebecca
text: You guys okay over here?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, we're fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_flirting_] Well... you must be new here.  I surely would have remembered such a pretty face as yours.

speaker: Niles
text: You're overcompensating.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  We're fine.  Bye-bye. [_she leaves_] I'm just baffled, Niles.  Obviously, Gil Chesterton explains "Chesty" but little else.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps you should tackle this from a free-association standpoint.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, must we?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, now... focus on any detail in the motel room. What's the first thing that pops into your mind?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... a crescent-shaped lamp.

speaker: Niles
text: Perfect - crescent-shaped lamp.  Run with that. Crescent... moon... Daphne Moon... French maid... brass bed... satin robe...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  This is my dream!

speaker: Niles
text: I was just showing you the process.

speaker: Frasier
text: You were three words away from a cigarette!

speaker: Niles
text: [_outraged_] Your turn!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.

speaker: Niles
text: Crescent lamp.

speaker: Frasier
text: Crescent... croissant... butter... apricot jam... hunger... food... diet!  My God, I've been on a diet.  Do you think that's useful?

speaker: Niles
text: You could stand to lose a few pounds.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just wait a minute.  Gil is a restaraunt critic - a gourmet. Perhaps he's symbolic of the food I've been denying myself.

speaker: Niles
text: That would explain why you're naked in the dream.  It's when we're naked that we're most self-conscious about our bodies.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and most vulnerable to the way society "tattoos" us with labels about our appearance!  God, that's it, Niles! The dream is simply telling me that I've been too rigid about my diet!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you'll know tonight.  If this is the correct interpretation, the conflict will have passed from your unconscious to your conscious mind.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, the dream will have served its purpose.

speaker: Niles
text: And you will no longer be plagued by it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God, Niles.  I've nailed it all right.  I really have. Finally, for the first time in weeks they'll be no tequila bottles, no tattoo, no half-naked man in my bed. [_he looks up to see Rebecca standing at their table_] So then, the Rabbi says... _FADE TO:  Scene Four - The Motel Room. Once again, Frasier is in bed.  The tequila bottle is still there, and he still has the tattoo.  The shower turns off and out from the bathroom steps a rather buxom woman wearing only a towel.  Frasier looks pleasantly surprised._

speaker: Woman
text: Oh, I'm sorry... wrong room. [_leaves_] _Frasier's expression turns to disappointment.  Gil suddenly appears lying next to Frasier in bed._

speaker: Gil
text: That does it.  We're finding another motel. _SMASH CUT TO: Frasier again wakes up from his dream in a panic.  He notices something under the covers next to him.  He cautiously pulls back the covers to reveal Eddie.  He isn't any more pleased about this.  End of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene One - The elevator at the Elliot Bay Towers. Daphne and Martin are in the back of the elevator.  The doors open and a woman gets on, standing in front of Daphne and Martin.  Daphne says hello and they lapse into silence for a moment.  She and Martin then begin to speak to each other in a conspiratorial tone._

speaker: Daphne
text: Someone followed me again last night.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, you're just being paranoid.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm telling you, they're onto me.

speaker: Martin
text: Come on.  Nobody could recognize you after all that plastic surgery.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's what Marlena thought.

speaker: Martin
text: Marlena got sloppy.  She never should have gone back to Zurich.

speaker: Daphne
text: I just don't want any more bloodshed.

speaker: Martin
text: Relax.  You're home free.

speaker: Daphne
text: You don't know the Woodchuck and his ways. _The doors open and the woman rushes out in fear.  Martin and Daphne break down laughing._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, we're terrible!

speaker: Martin
text: We are?  You are!  "The Woodchuck and his ways"?

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, we really should stop doing this.  It's not nice.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, you're right.  We won't do it anymore.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_as soon as the doors close, to Martin_] How'd you get the stuff through Customs?

speaker: Martin
text: They never check the wooden leg. _CUT TO: Frasier's apartment.  Frasier is pacing the living room as Niles sits at the couch, poring over psychology textbooks._

speaker: Frasier
text: The answer has got to be in there somewhere!

speaker: Niles
text: Here's something. [_reads_] "Dreams as an expression of wish fulfillment."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_grabs the book_] Moving on.

speaker: Daphne
text: Goodness, are you two still here?

speaker: Martin
text: What are you working on?

speaker: Frasier
text: Nothing.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm helping Frasier interpret a dream he's been having. You know, maybe Dad can help.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_alarmed_] No, no, no... don't want to bore Dad with the details of this particular dream.

speaker: Niles
text: Dreams can be rooted in childhood experience.  Maybe Dad remembers something you've repressed.

speaker: Martin
text: Gee, I don't know.  If it's about when you were a kid I've repressed a lot of that myself. [_exits to the kitchen_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, this is not a dream I wish to share with Dad, thank you very much.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we've exhausted every other interpretation.  So, I guess it's back to dreams as wish fulfillment...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad... [_he moves to the kitchen where Martin is making a sandwich_] Would you mind listening to my dream to see if it conjures up any memories from my childhood?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on.  You're making too much out of this.  It's a dream.  Dreams are weird.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, Dad.  I wouldn't ask if it weren't really bothering me.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, all right... go on.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right... it starts out in a little motel room.  I have a tattoo on my arm - "Chesty"...

speaker: Martin
text: See?  That's weird.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Then out from the bathroom steps a... All right, now before I continue, let me remind you that this is a dream. Not to be confused with reality. [_Martin nods, still busy with his sandwich_] Out from the bathroom steps a man... [_off Martin's concerned expression_] -eating lion!

speaker: Martin
text: [_relieved_] Oh, see?  There again, weird.  Look, dreams come, they go.  They don't mean anything.  Except, you know, if you're lucky, every once in awhile you might have one that's a lot of fun.  Like, you hit a home run in the World Series or you're in the jungle with Jayne Mansfield and she gets bit by a snake.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: You know who Jayne Mansfield is, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: You know what you do when you're bit by a snake, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad. [_leaves_]

speaker: Martin
text: [_to himself_] Wish I knew what I had for dinner that night. _Frasier enters the living room to find Niles and Daphne on the couch, chatting about Frasier's dream._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I get it.  Chesty refers to Gil Chesterton.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you gossipy fishwife!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_standing_] There's no reason to feel self-conscious, Dr. Crane.  We've all had dreams like that.  I had one about a girl I shared a flat with once - a gymnast.

speaker: Niles
text: [_standing_] Go on, Daphne.  This could be significant.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I remember we were doing stretches in the gymnasium, when suddenly we decided to take off all our clothes and go for a bounce on the trampoline. [_giggles_] The next thing you know, I'm chasing her around the pommel horse.  Oh, never mind...

speaker: Niles
text: [_aroused_] Don't stop now! [_off their looks_] This could help us. [_sits_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, actually, I do have a theory of my own about your dream, if you'd like to hear it.

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well... in your dream, who was in the shower?  Gil.  What is a shower?  Running water.  Who needs water?  Fish.  What do fish have?  Gills!  Do you see where I'm going?

speaker: Frasier
text: Insane?

speaker: Daphne
text: It could be a dream about the loss of a beloved childhood pet.

speaker: Martin
text: [_entering from the kitchen with Eddie_] Thanks a lot, Eddie. Forty-five minutes in the park, you don't have to go.  I get one bite into my sandwich and you give me the look.

speaker: Daphne
text: Mr. Crane, did Dr. Crane ever have a goldfish growing up?

speaker: Martin
text: A fish?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, as a pet.

speaker: Martin
text: How would I know?  That was Hester's department. [_to Eddie_] Come on, let's go. [_leaves_]

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, are you thinking what I'm thinking?

speaker: Frasier
text: That Dad can interpret the looks from his dog and has only the spottiest recollections of our childhoods?

speaker: Niles
text: No.  No, no, no.  Hester - Hesty.  The tattoo - that's only one letter away from Chesty!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, are you saying that the dream could have been about mother?

speaker: Niles
text: Well?

speaker: Frasier
text: I suppose I could have misread the tattoo. [_rolls up his shirt sleeve_] Yes, yes... this freckle pattern here on my arm could be mistaken for a "C."

speaker: Daphne
text: And what swims in the sea?  Fish! [_off their looks_] All right, all right I'll go. [_exits to her room_]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, so the tattoo could have said "Hesty."  But the problem is, I don't ever remember Dad calling her that.

speaker: Frasier
text: But who's to say he didn't? _They both gasp and run to the elevator, where Martin is still waiting with Eddie._

speaker: Both
text: Dad, Dad... Dad, Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Did you ever have a nickname for Mother?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for God's sakes!  Is this to do with that stupid dream?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, this is really important!

speaker: Niles
text: Any pet name?  A term of endearment?

speaker: Martin
text: Well... when we were first married I used to call her "Honey."  And then... there was a time after that that I started calling her "Sweetie."

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sure there's a delicious anecdote behind each one of those.  But did you ever call her "Hesty"?

speaker: Martin
text: "Hesty"?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_forcefully_] Oh, come on, think, man!  Even once!  Once, in all the years you lived together?!

speaker: Martin
text: [_nervously_] We-Well... I don't know. [_elevator doors open_] I- I guess...

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, maybe once... [_stumbles into the elevator, disturbed_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you Dad! [_doors close_] Well, there it is!  I must have heard him call her "Hesty" once and neatly tucked it away into my subconscious.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, it's so obvious!  Gil is a food critic.  Food, criticism...

speaker: Both
text: Mother!

speaker: Niles
text: It's the classic Oedipal dream!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes... only I was so frightened by my sexual urges to be with my mother that I transformed her into a man! Oh, what a relief!  I've been wringing my hands over nothing. I mean, it's okay.  All I want to do is have sex with my dead mother! _Frasier turns to see that a woman has been standing by the elevator doors and has overheard him.  He sheepishly enters his apartment.  FADE TO:  Scene Six - the Motel Room. The scene reveals a painting of bananas and swords above the bed where Frasier is sleeping.  He awakens to find the tattoo of "Chesty" still on his arm and the sound of the shower running.  He is exasperated.  The shower stops and he turns to the bathroom door with a look of apprehension._

speaker: Frasier
text: Mom?  Mommy?

speaker: Gil
text: [_entering_] Patience, Daddy! _SMASH CUT TO: Frasier again wakes up from his dream in a panic and switches on the light in his bedroom.  FADE TO:_ **THANK GOD HE WAS WRONG ABOUT THAT "MOTHER" THING** _Scene Two - Frasier's apartment. The middle of the night.  Frasier is poring over textbooks at the kitchen table.  Martin enters from his bedroom, groaning._

speaker: Martin
text: You'd think by now I'd know better than to have that third Slim Jim before going to bed.  Couldn't sleep either, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  Frankly, I'm sort of afraid to go back to sleep. It's that damn dream again.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, what are you worried about?  It's just a dream. Worst case scenario - the man-eating lion leaps on top of you and mauls you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Dad, I wasn't completely truthful with you before. The dream is really about me in a motel room with a male companion, Gil Chesterton.

speaker: Martin
text: You don't care if I ever sleep again, do you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, please, I'd really like to discuss this!

speaker: Martin
text: No, Frasier, please.  This makes me very uncomfortable. [_he enters the kitchen with Frasier following him_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, please...

speaker: Martin
text: I know, I know... in your generation, men talk about everything.  Everything's out in the open. [_he begins to nervously clean the refrigerator and countertop, avoiding eye contact_] You know what really drives me crazy is the way you all touch each other.  Everybody hugs, you know?  In my generation it was a... a handshake.  That was good enough. Maybe if you felt especially close to someone you'd touch him on the shoulder, but never for more than two seconds. And don't talk to me about football players patting people's butts and everything, because that's different - that's sports, that's like war.  Now, goodnight, son. [_exits to the living room_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad...!

speaker: Martin
text: Look, if you want to tell me something, write it on a post- it and stick it on the fridge.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, I really want to talk about this! [_Martin finally stops and faces Frasier_] I've exhausted every other possible interpretation of this dream.  Is it possible my subconscious is trying to tell me something about my sexuality?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's ridiculous!

speaker: Frasier
text: Is it?  I was sensitive as a child; I didn't go in for sports. God, it's every cliche in the book.  Surely it must have occurred to you at some point?  You refused to take me to see "West Side Story" on my eighth birthday.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, because of the gangs.  That's scary for kids.

speaker: Frasier
text: Even gangs that dance?

speaker: Martin
text: Especially gangs that dance! [_then_] All right.  Yeah... okay, yeah, I thought about it.  But no, Frasier, no... I don't believe that.  And you know why?  Because you would have known by now.  Your unconscious or whatever the hell you call it could no more have kept its yap shut than the rest of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I suppose you're right.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Now, come on, it's after 3:00.  You're gonna be all worn out before your show tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: What a tragedy that would be.

speaker: Martin
text: Now what are you complaining about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't know.  I just haven't had any really interesting calls lately.  I'm beginning to question whether I'm not bored with psychiatry. [_sits at the table_]

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, you'd never know it with the way you got your nose stuck in all those books.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's true.  The one saving grace about this dream is it's given me a chance to flex my analytical muscle a bit.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, maybe it wasn't so bad after all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait a minute.  Could that be what this has been all about? I've been so intellectually unchallenged lately by my show that my mind had to create a dream that defies interpretation just to give me a challenge?

speaker: Martin
text: I don't know.  Keep talking, you're making me sleepy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, no... that's got to be it! [_stands_] My show hasn't provided me with a single patient worthy of my skills and I had to invent one myself - me!  Oh, God!  What a relief.  At last, finally, to bed.  Dad, you've witnessed an epiphany! [_they move to the hall_]

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, God, I got to get you to put this on tape.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_o.s._] Off we go.  To sleep, perchance NOT to dream. _FADE TO:  Scene Four - The Motel Room. Frasier is once again lying in the bed, asleep.  He awakens to find the tattoo is now gone and there is no more tequila bottle.  He sits up and listens for the shower.  Hearing nothing, he lies back, relieved.  Suddenly, there is a knock on the door.  Frasier sits up in surprise and says "Come in."  A man enters, the psychiatrist Dr. Siegmund Freud._

speaker: Freud
text: Dr. Crane, Dr. Siegmund Freud.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my goodness! [_they shake hands_] It's quite an honor!

speaker: Freud
text: The honor is all mine.  I gave you a complex psychological problem and you solved it.  You are a brilliant psychiatrist.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's very flattering.  You know, there are so many things I'd like to ask you!

speaker: Freud
text: In good time, my boy.  In good time.  Right now, we have more important matters. _He takes out some breath freshener and sprays it into his mouth. To Frasier's astonishment, Freud then climbs into bed with Frasier and lies back, spreading out his arms for an embrace.  CUT TO: an exterior shot of Frasier's apartment building, where we see a lone light switch on at the 19th floor.  It appears Frasier is in for another sleepless night._ [_N.B.  For you Frasier trivia buffs, this is the only time Frasier's apartment has been shown from an exterior point of view._]
